Something to think about is that problem solving is not like doing math. It's not an equation with a problem on one side and a solution on the other. Yo solve problems correctly you need to be able to see and understand the relationships between all the interacting parts of the environment that the problem exists in, you then alter the environment so that the problem disappears. Solutions always make the problem disappear. This is also different from solving a puzzle which is also not a problem. Please do not describe puzzles as problems because they are not. It's very important that you understand that solving a "puzzle" is not solving a "problem", and finding an "answer" to a mathematical "equation" is also not solving a "problem". It does confuse people though so its important that it is clarified. Too often I see/hear people using the term problem when describing a puzzle or an equation which is completely wrong.

Regarding the probability problem, there is an easier way to solve it given the multiple choice format. Of course exploiting the format is not good problem solving, but in this case it's valid as the real question is not what the exact value, but what range it falls in. As such, there are legitimate problem solving techniques to answer this question. What you'd do is also define an infinite series describing the probability of it being odd, so that partial evaluation of it defines an upper bound, while partial evaluation of the original series gives a lower bound. You only need to evaluate a finite number of terms in both series before the bounds fall in one of the given ranges. As a result, one can avoid actually finding an exact solution to the infinite series, which requires much more powerful mathematical tools like analysis. In practice, such approximate solutions are enough for many real world problems, and in mathematical problems as well as something like ln(2) is just symbols, but knowing you can compute an arbitrary close upper and lower bound makes it well-defined. Lastly, it works a rigorous check. If the means for computing the bounds were logically valid, than it's guaranteed to be able to confirm if the calculated value is within bounds, while the Monte-Carlo simulation only give a probabilistic estimate.

at about 13:24 "strangely useful" -- one old artist trick to find the center of a circle uses this "angle from the circumference is 1/2 the angle from the center" trick. Basically, you put the corner of a sheet of paper on the circle touching the inside edge of the circle. The edges of the paper will intersect the circle at opposite ends of a full diameter. Basically, the 90 degree corner meets a 180 degree angle from the center. Mark both intersection points and you can split the circle exactly in half. Move the corner and mark again, and you get two lines the intersect in the center.

1. Engage the limbic system enough to be motivated to solve the problem. Use no more emotion than that.
2. Fully define the problem(s) and the solution(s) sought.
3. Gather information and tools required to manipulate the givens until the variables are accounted for.
4. Develop the solution.
5. Test the solution.
6. Adjust as necessary and take note of any new insights that can be used as tools in the next session of problem solving.

Take note that this applies everywhere, even in personal and political venues. If your “solution” is to vote for the most popular and least qualified among us to “solve” societies problems, you actually become part of the problem.

I distinctly remember classmates bellyaching about when we would use algebra in “real life.”

ALL the time. You use problem solving ALL the time. Mathematics just happens to be the pure abstraction of all instances of problems people will encounter in life. This is why solving how you send an army to a castle with eight different roads than cannot support the weight of your army is the same solution as treating cancer with radiation. They are two seemingly different situations, but are abstractly the same problem. For both, you need the full effect at a central location without damaging the path to get there: you decrease the power and send them along different paths to converge where they are needed.

Problem-Solving Tips
1. Use the defining features of the setup
2. Give things (meaningful) names.
3. Leverage Symmetry
4. Try describing one object two deifferent ways.
5. Draw a picture. [Have some numbers? Make them coords!]
6. Ask a simpler version of the problem.
[Inbetween tip: Don't collapse things too soon; have a memory where things came from]
7. Read a lot, and think about problems a lot.
8. Always gut-check your answer!
9. Learn at least a little bit of programming.

My approach to the probability problem:

First, notice the 50% chance of rounding to 0. For the remaining terms, suppose X is the bigger number in floor(x/y).

With one value fixed, we can actually "scale up" so that x = 1 and y = whatever it was multiplied by some ratio. This won't change the probabilities in any way.

Now, we simply have floor(1/y), and a tiny bit of thinking gets you to (1/2 -1/3) + (1/4-1/5) + ... + (1/2n - 1/2n+1) using similar reasoning has Grant's. I didn't know how to deal with this series, and after some googling to dead ends on how to simplify this I suddenly remembered that this is similar to the sum for ln(2). I looked that one up and then got the answer from there... almost.

The mistake I made was different than the one he did. The mistake I made was that for the non-zero even numbers (and odd numbers), they occur exactly 50% of the time! so I forgot to multiply my 1-ln(2) by a half (because only half the time is x > y) - a common probability mistake!

I hope that reasoning is clear, and helpful to someone.

17:47 I rather like to think of it this way.
This doesn't really help in the process of problem solving at that point, but really shows some more aspects of math that may be helpful later, not just in solving problems but also for delight.
The first step is the same, try describing both sides of the equation as the same quantity and continue thinking as Grant mentioned... But once I'm done with that and get the solution, I like to come back to the point where I deliberately chose one side of the equation as describing a quantity, and not some other thing, so as to look at it in two different ways. And then, I ask myself the equation that I'm after never told me to treat both sides as the same quantity.. It just means, that any interpretation of the two sides of the equation have to be equal. For example, even if one side is treated as area and other as length, if the equation holds, they must have the same magnitude...
Note that I am NOT saying that area and length can be equal, they are totally different ideas, but the the ones to choose them are we and unless we restrict us to not including the notion of ONLY MAGNITUDES..

Just for an example, consider a seemingly simple equation 3 × 4 = 12
Consider both sides as lengths... You can imagine 3 being a scale factor for 4 m that gives out 12 m ( You have 3 rods of length 4m placed right after each other and you have total 12 m of rod)
BUT
Another way you can look at it is take LHS to be area of a rectangle of sides 3 m and 4 m, and RHS as just length, just because the equation also says "magnitude of length of a 12 m long rod and the magnitude of an area of a 3 by 4 rectangle also MUST be equal".. Just another way of looking at it... All I really want to say is an equation tells more truths about nature if we break the barrier of treating both sides as the same quantity though it may not be directly helpful in solving the particular problem or decoding what it means.

And this can be generalized to more complicated looking mathematical equations not just the one I mentioned above...
I believe the more ways we have to look at the same thing, the more beautiful it appears in maths...

I'd love to know others' views on this too..

By the way, Grant, You do an unbelievably amazing job explaining mathematical ideas and concepts...

I'm not sure I can fully agree with the conclusion regarding the value of p.  Certainly, if the number of numbers from which we can randomly choose is finite, then as the number of numbers increases without limit, p will approach 0.5(2 - ln(2)).  And, in the empirical case, the computer only has access to a finite number of distinct numbers, so of course it will show p approaching 0.5(2 - ln(2)).  But if we truly had access to all real numbers in the interval [0,1], then the concept of probability would break down or be ambiguous.  The number of paired numbers that round down to 2 would be the same as the number of paired numbers that round down to 0, which is infinite, which is also the same number of paired numbers that would round down to an even number in general, which is also the same number of paired numbers that would round down to an odd number.  So p could actually be just 50%.

I had a puzzle I was working on the other day. I won't describe the actual problem here, but it was one where I had to find a way to arrange a bunch of objects in a grid such that given constraints were satisfied. Imagine that it was related to something one might study in combinatorics.
What initially made the problem difficult was having an overwhelming number of options to try. There were so many ways to arrange the pieces, almost all of which fail to meet the constraints. I keep trying to use trial and error, but over and over and over kept running into dead ends: given how I already tried to place half the pieces, there was no valid way to place the remaining pieces.
Then I changed my approach. I tried assuming the solution would be as beautiful and symmetric as possible. That meant assuming additional constraints on the problem, beyond those originally given. This could well not work, simply leading to the new version of the problem having no solution at all. But having no other clear way to proceed, this was worth a try. In my case, assuming those additional constraints served to quite significantly reduce the number of possibilities I'd need to try. It reduced the possibilities so much that I was able to use trial and error to find a working solution within just a few more minutes. That was satisfying.
This is probably not a problem solving approach that in general will work very often. But when one sees no other option, it may work as a last resort!

At school we did those Mathematics Challenge papers, and after a semester of uni I went back to do one again. It seemed a lot easier. It wasn't because I'd learnt new tools as such, because they were all meant to be stuff you'd learn at school, but the way of approaching them that you learn at uni is different. One thing I think of a lot is when you have a question, think about what information is provided and what that implies about the answer. If it seems like a crucial bit of information is missing, it likely means that the answer is invariant when that value changes, and so you can likely solve for edge cases.

Problem solving tips
1. Use the defining features of the set up.
2. Give things (meaningful) names
3. Leverage symmetry
4. Try describing one object two different ways
5. Draw a picture. [Have some numbers? Make them coordinates!]
6. Ask a simpler version of the problem
7. Read a lot, and think about problems a lot.
8. Always gut-check your answer!
9. Learn at least a little bit of programming

I noticed something very fun about the final answer to the probability question of ½(2 - ln(2)) - it simplifies to 1 - ½ln(2). Which made me realise that ½ln(2) is the probability of x/y rounding down to being an odd number. Which makes sense, because the area of each of the unshaded regions is going to be ½(1 - ½), ½(⅓ - ¼), etc. and so their sum will be ½(1 - ½ + ⅓ - ¼ +...) - in other words, ½ln(2) ! So your deliberate mistake served an extra purpose here :)

It may be overkill but I calculated the probability of floor(x/y) being even using a surface integral. I did 1 - ∫∫ floor(x/y) dA over the region [0, 1] × [0, 1]

Another way of looking at the "mistake" at the end - the sum S represents the area of the strips that result in x/y rounding down to an odd number. To find the answer for the even numbers, leverage the fact that in probability P(even) = 1 - P(odd) in this context

This results in P(even) = 1 - (1/2)ln(2), which is equivalent to the final answer given.

I want to share a personal life experience about the "Read a lot and solvr many problems" tip. When I started college, I dabbled into competitive programming. Which is essentially solving math problems through coding. And we had thia little group where we would solve problems together, contest-style, and then at the end everyone would explain problems they managed to solve. I was one of the new guys in the group, and because I wasn't a very good student in highschool, I was among the worst problem solvers there. And there wad this one guy in that group who was visibly better than anyone else. He had these absolutely crazy ideas of applying some seemingly completely unrelated concepts for certain problems and I remember looking at him at the blackboard and thinking "How the hell is this guy getting these ideas? He is so smart". And then one day I decided I wanted to become good, too. And I started solving problems on various sites. I solved over 2000 problems that year. And as I was solving them, I found myself reading about a lot of theorems and algorithms, which were needed to solve these problems. And eventually I became one of the best competitive programmers in my country, with some decent international results too. I remember I got to team up with that guy I was talking about for some contests, and I felt extremely honored. I felt like I'd achieved my goal of getting to his level. And I feel like the problem solving skills I gained along the way helped me a lot in real-life decisions. This whole deal happened about 5 years ago, and I had plenty of time to notice how I have taken a very different approach to what I do when faced with a life-altering decision than how I used to do it back then. Anyway, the moral of the story is: if you want to become a good problem solver, just solve a lot of problems. Even if you start from the very bottom, after a few thousand problems solved, you are guaranteed to pick up some things along the way.

Make things as easy as possible but not easier.

3Blue1Brown's sixth point is crucial. If you have a 3 dimensional problem make it 2d first. Do you have 4 Variables? Start off with 3 Variables first. This is probably the most important 3B1B video of them all. Here, Grant distils all his years of learning and inquiry into a few actionable ideas, expressed simply.

As an engineering senior who barely tolerates pure mathematics, I have seen Grant mention these ideas before and noted the similarity to the process of solving an engineering problem. By following a systematic and disciplined method one can make sense of a complicated practical system and solve for all kinds of unknowns. We always define our system, draw a diagram, look for symmetry, find alternate expressions for variables, plot data to look for connections and so on. And the teaching process is designed to take us from simple problems to more complex ones, but often the key to a tricky problem is to imagine a simplified or extreme case ('what it [x] were zero, or infinite?') and generalise from there. Of course we have the luxury as students of saying 'assume [friction, or some other pesky state-dependent variable] is negligible.'

And with many mechanical systems, understanding the geometry is often the most important step.

"I think the truth of the matter, is a lot of what looks like insight and ingenuity, is really just pattern recognition but wearing a little bit of added clothing" is probably the most validating statement I have ever heard as an amateur mathematician and lover of "wisdom." So often I am accused of fabricating new wisdom or begin to ask myself if I am attempting to fabricate new math, only to assure myself that I am simply combining two or more patterns I have heard before to make a more relevant mapping of a given situation.
For example, as a young child I reinvented the saying "Do unto others as they would have done unto them" by taking the "Golden Rule" and adding to it the concept I had recently learned that different people like different flavors of jelly on their bread, along with the assumption that, since they had tried all of them, no one was wrong about what they liked. (Ah elementary school statistics. I miss math and science having snacks.) It was clear to me even as I said it, that it was not novel, I had just combined two patterns to make myself better at reducing social interaction to heuristics, but I was lauded for ingenuity and creativity (and reprimanded for derailing the class).

Ah, so at last you stepped into a field where I'm more comfortable and could actually say something, rather than listen with my jaw dropped to the floor. :) So asking about tips to solve problems in general is a weaker form of a question about an automated, formal procedure to solve problems in general. And so it might have been nice to point out at the very beginning, that it's already proven that such a procedure cannot exist (precise formulation of the problem was to find a formal procedure, that for any statement in a mathematical theory would indicate whether the statement is true or false), so tips is all that we can ever hope for. It happens to be one of my favourite achievements in 20th century mathematics. It was proven independently in 1930s by two mathematicians in very different ways. One of them was Alan Turing (who imagined the famous Turing Machine and used it for this very proof) and Alonzo Church (who used his own invention of Lambda Calculus). They actually met later and together proved that both solutions are equivalent to each other (if I remember correctly it was Turing's PhD thesis and Church was his supervisor), laying foundation for modern computer science, especially programming. Actually all modern programming languages are in one way or another based either on Turing Machine or Lambda Calculus.
